prompt: Set up a pull request for my work - I need the title to follow conventional commits, link to the related epic, and make sure I haven't missed any required sections in our PR template
baseline_response:
I'll help you set up a pull request (PR) following best practices. I'll provide a template that includes conventional commits, epic linking, and typical PR template sections.

Here's a comprehensive PR template:

```markdown
## Type of Change
<!-- Choose one type and remove the others -->
- [ ] üêõ Bug Fix
- [ ] ‚ú® Feature
- [ ] üîß Refactor
- [ ] üìù Documentation
- [ ] üöÄ Performance Improvement
- [ ] üß™ Test

## Related Epic/Issue
<!-- Link to the associated epic or issue -->
Relates to: [EPIC-XXX](link-to-epic-or-issue)

## Description
### What does this PR do?
<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of the changes -->

### Why were these changes made?
<!-- Explain the motivation and context behind the changes -->

## Checklist
- [ ] I have performed a self-review of my code
- [ ] I have added tests that prove my fix/feature
- [ ] My changes generate no new warnings
- [ ] I have commented my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [ ] I have updated documentation accordingly

## Additional Context
<!-- Add any other relevant information about the PR -->

## Screenshots (if applicable)
<!-- Include before/after screenshots or GIFs -->
```

For the PR title, use conventional commits format:
```
<type>(optional scope): <description>

Examples:
- feat(auth): add login with Google
- fix(payment): resolve transaction timeout issue
- docs(readme): update installation instructions
```

Steps to create the PR:
1. Ensure all checks in the template are completed
2. Choose the appropriate type
3. Link to the related epic/issue
4. Provide a clear, descriptive title
5. Fill out all sections thoroughly

Would you like me to help you draft the specific details for your PR?
skill_response:
I'll help you set up the pull request systematically. To do this effectively, I'll need some additional information from you:

1. What type of work are you submitting? (e.g., feature, fix, docs, refactor)
2. What is the specific scope or component of your changes?
3. What is the brief description of your changes?
4. What is the related epic or issue number?
5. Can you share the PR template from your repository?

Once you provide these details, I'll help you craft a pull request that:
- Uses conventional commits for the title
- Links to the related epic
- Ensures all required template sections are completed

Could you share more context about your work and the repository's PR template?
reasoning: Response B is significantly more helpful and actionable. While Response A only asks for information without providing immediate value, Response B delivers a comprehensive solution including a detailed PR template with all common sections, clear conventional commit formatting examples, and a step-by-step process. Response B addresses all three user requirements: conventional commit title format, epic linking structure, and a complete template to ensure no required sections are missed. It provides immediate practical value that the user can implement right away, while still offering to help with specific details. Response A requires additional back-and-forth before providing any concrete assistance.
